_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CEDAR BAY GENERATING FACILITY



Cedar Bay Generating Plant is operated and managed by Cedar Bay Generating Company L.P.(CBGC). CBGC operates the Cedar Bay facility in  accordance with stringent policies and protocols designed to protect the health and safety of our employees and neighbors, as well as the environment. Responsibility for safety and environmental performance at the plant is shared by every employee. This message is communicated through ongoing training programs designed to raise awareness and build necessary on-the-job skills. Performance in these areas are regularly evaluated through inspections and audits with the goal of measuring progress and identifying areas for continued improvement. 



As is the case for many facilities, Cedar Bay Generating Plant's participation in the RMP program is triggered by the use of only one substance (ammonium hydroxide) on-site in quantities that exceed a threshold amount. At this facility, ammonium hydroxide is the key ingredient in the facility's air pollution control system for NOx control. On both the design and operation of our plants, among the most important priorities is the minimization of air emissions, including nitrogen oxides (Nox). Nitrogen Oxides are a primary contributor to smog. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and state regulators have identified Nox emissions reductions as one of the most important keys to achieving national air quality improvement goals. In order to help achieve this objective, the Cedar Bay facility employs emissions control technology that uses ammonium hydroxide to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions.



The Cedar Bay Generating Facility (S.I.C. Code 4911) uses one regulated substance, aqueous ammonia (CAS Number 7664-41-7) in the Selective Non-catalytic reduction (SNCR) process. Aqueous ammonia is routinely delivered at 29 percent ammonia concentration to the facility. 



The hazard assessment was performed on the SNCR process using the United States Environmental Prote

ction Agency (USEPA) RMP*Comp Model. The worst-case release scenario was assumed to be the release of the entire amount of aqueous ammonia in storage outside for a duration of 10 minutes. The alternative release scenario selected for the facility was a failure due to a break in the 2 inch aqueous ammonia line between the pump and control valve. For both scenarios, the off-site consequence analysis indicated that an off-site receptor (industrial facility) could be potentially impacted by the release of aqueous ammonia. Although off-site areas would be impacted, the Facility believes that safety procedures and mitigation measures will reduce the potential for off-site consequences and subsequent risks to the surrounding environment. The Facility's safety devices include alarms and automatic system shut-off devices. 



In order to fulfill the requirements of the Risk Management Program (RMP), the Facility has developed an accidental release prevention program and emergency action plan.  The accidental release prevention program satisfies the requirements for the USEPA RMP and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The prevention program ensures that the Facility is operated under safe conditions and that any risk of an accidental release of aqueous ammonia due to human error or equipment failure is minimized. The program has been written to reduce the potential of an accidental release due to human error or equipment failure. On order to prevent the release of aqueous ammonia due to human error, the Facility's prevention program ensures that operating procedures are current and reviewed annually. Training also plays a vital part in the program.  Employees working with the SNCR process are required to be trained in the process and the hazards of aqueous ammonia.



To prevent equipment failure that could result in an accidental release, the Facility's program ensures that equipment is inspected, tested, and

preventive maintenance performed in accordance with accepted engineering practices and includes manufacturer's recommendations.  All equipment pertaining to the SNCR process is maintained, inspected, and tested in accordance with a planned maintenance schedule.



All existing equipment has been designed according to applicable standards and codes.  The Facility maintains records and documentation on equipment inspection and tests.  Precautions are taken to ensure that new equipment and processes are inspected and tested, that all changes on the process are authorized, and employees are informed of changes.



The Facility performs a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) every 5 years to address the hazards in the SNCR process and to evaluate and control where the potential for an aqueous ammonia release exists.  Employees may be involved in determining hazards of the process and subsequent consequences. The PHA conducted in 2014 found the process to be operating safely and no major changes were recommended.



Active employee participation will ensure the success of the RMP at the Facility.  Employees have been assigned various tasks to ensure that all elements of the RMP are implemented.  The Facility has developed specific procedures to assist employees in performing, recording, and documenting the various elements of the RMP.



Since the time of the submittal of the original Risk Management Plan in 1999, there have been zero releases of aqueous ammonia at the Facility. However, in the event that there is an accidental release, an Emergency Action Plan has been written in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.38.  The Facility is also included in the community emergency response plan.  Employees at the Facility do not respond to accidental releases, but coordinate with outside responders.  Therefore, in accordance with 40 CFR 68.90, an Emergency Response Program is not required for the Facility.  In the event that an aqueous ammonia release occurs, all employees are required to e

vacuate the process area and report the incident. The emergency action plan consists of evacuation procedures, Facility emergency numbers, and coordination with Jacksonville Fire Rescue Hazardous Materials Management Team.  The plan also addresses notification procedures to the public and the local emergency response agency.



As the operators of this facility, Cogentrix takes seriously its commitment to accident prevention and effective emergency response.  While no industrial site is entirely free from risk, it is our goal, through continuous improvement, to manage risks, as effectively as possible.  This plan demonstrates that the company has the programs in place both to minimize the possibility of a release and to respond to one in the unlikely event that one occurs.
